column4: The fact that Ubuntu is on partition 1 and Windows is on partition 3, is no reason for having troubles. The sequence of installing Ubuntu and Windows may be the reason of your trouble.
I did this before and it worked but it was on seperate hard drives.
Ubuntu and Windows can coexist on separate drives and on the same drive as well. In latter case they need to be on separate partitions.

they are. I Used all 4 Physical Partitions on the hard drive. Its a 250 gig drive with the first half being taken up by ubuntu. the next quarter is a fat32 partition so i can transfer files without any major problems and the last quarter is for windows xp.
afterward is the swap for linux.
Linux has no problem with it.
Your arrangement of partitions is not the cause of your windows troubles.
any idea what else it could be then?
I have ideas, but too many to list them here. Please pastebin dmesg messages so that one can analyze any error messages in them and advise you.
I can't pastebin the messages. They happen half way through the boot.
I do not understand your sentence: "They happen half way through the boot" as English is not my mother's language. Say it in other words.
Windows reboots during the install. When it does that's when it tells me it has a  disk error and asks me to press a key to restart.
It is strongly recommended that you first install Windows and Ubuntu afterwards. Have you kept this sequence?

no. I have been running Ubuntu for a while now and just recently decided to make my system dual-boot. It worked when both were on different hard drives but now it gives me this error. I can fix GRUB after the install if i could just get windows installed.

Apparently installing both operating systems on the same hard drive places higher requirements to both operating systems. So I recommend to first install Windows and Linux afterwards. This worked for me on two laptops. This also made less trouble in my local computer club. And this is what I have read many times in forums.
I guess a backup and reformat is my best option. Thanks.

A backup is advisable. Yes. I am not sure if an explicit reformat is necessary before you start installing Windows. I believe the usual Windows install CDs will format first anyway. But you might ask a more knowledgeable person for that.
They do format. Its a pain in the butt. Thanks!
